Derek Pappas wrote:
>> What's the hardware like?

> $ cat /proc/meminfo
> MemTotal:      1026792 kB

Your screenshot reported 1.3GB heap used; 1.8GB heap max/allocated. With 
only 1GB RAM, that means lots of swapping, which probably explains the 
slowness. Java heap memory usage is very non-local -- essentially by 
design of the garbage-collection system -- and so you always want the 
heap size to be less than RAM. I would recommend a max-heap setting of 
no more than 700MB-800MB on a 1GB machine.

> 	ï¿½ Frontier report
> 15179 queues: 191 active (50 in-process; 31 ready; 110 snoozed); 78  
> inactive; 0 retired; 14910 exhausted

I believe the swapping is enough to explain the slowdown, but this 
*might* be slightly suggestive there are a disproportionate number of 
queues that are non-responsive. With typical politeness waits that are 
10X or more of the fetch-times, if the queues are all 'lively' (fetching 
quickly) then the total number of ready+snoozed queues would be larger 
than just 1.4 times the number of in-process queues, up to all the 
available inactive queues.

Looking at the full frontier report for queues that are in long 
(multi-minute) snoozes, or have odd domain names and have never made any 
progress, will be one indication that this is happening. Connect errors 
in the 'local-errors.log' are another indication.

When the queues' target hosts aren't responsive and not expected to 
become responsive, it's just an operator judgment call as to when to 
terminate the crawl.

I think you'll get much better performance if you restart with a 
max-heap (JVM -Xmx) below total RAM.
